q3.value: Gratitude to God is a very prevalent emotion among people who identify as religious, as well as those who don’t claim a religious affiliation. However, psychologists know little about fundamental issues concerning the nature, structure, and function of gratitude to God. The present study is exploratory in nature, aiming to investigate any emerging differences between gratitude to God and other types of gratitude. The purpose of this study is four-fold: 1) to investigate the differences in gratitude to God, gratitude to other abstract entities (e.g., country), gratitude to people, and general feelings of gratitude; 2) to pilot six experimental gratitude conditions: gratitude to God, gratitude to people, gratitude to parents, gratitude to country, general feelings of gratitude, and a control condition; 3) to explore behavioral giving patterns between participants in each gratitude condition; 4) to serve as the basis for future studies on gratitude to God.

q4.value:
Number of gratitude responses:
•	Participants in the gratitude to God (GTG) condition will list more items that they are grateful for than participants in all other conditions. 
•	Participants in the GTG and gratitude to Country condition will list more items for which they are grateful than participants in the gratitude to people and gratitude to parents conditions. 
•	Participants in the gratitude to parents condition will list fewer items for which they are grateful. Self-transcendent gratitude responses
•	Participants in the GTG condition will list more self-transcendent items than participants in all other conditions. 
•	Participants in the gratitude to country condition will list more self-transcendent items than participants in the gratitude to people condition. 
•	Participants in the gratitude to country condition will list more self-transcendent items than participants in the general gratitude condition. 
•	Participants in the gratitude to parents condition will list more self-transcendent items than participants in the general gratitude condition. 
•	Participants in the gratitude to parents condition will list more self-transcendent items than people in the gratitude to people condition. 
•	Participants in the gratitude to parents condition will list more self-transcendent items than people in the general gratitude condition. 
•	Higher organizational religious activity will predict higher frequencies of self-transcendent items that participants are grateful for. 
•	Higher non-organizational religious activity will predict higher frequencies of self-transcendent items that participants are grateful for. 
•	Higher levels religious activity will predict higher frequencies of self-transcendent items that participants are grateful for. 

Materialistic gratitude responses:
•	Participants in the GTG condition will list fewer materialistic items than participants in all other conditions.
•	Higher organizational religious activity will predict lower frequencies of materialistic items that participants are grateful for. 
•	Higher non-organizational religious activity will predict lower frequencies of materialistic items that participants are grateful for. 
•	Higher levels religious activity will predict lower frequencies of materialistic items that participants are grateful for. 

Positive and Negative Affect:
•	Participants in the gratitude conditions will experience more positive affect than the control. 
•	Participants in the GTG condition will experience more positive affect than the other conditions.
•	Participants in the gratitude conditions will experience less negative affect than participants in all other conditions.
•	Participants in the GTG condition will experience less negative affect than participants in all 
other conditions.
•	Participants in the GTG condition will experience more "other-praising" (expansive) emotions than participants in all other conditions.
•	Participants in all the gratitude conditions will experience more "other-praising" (expansive) emotions than participants in the non-gratitude control condition.
•	Higher levels of organizational religious activity will predict greater experience of "other-praising" emotions. 
•	Higher levels of non- organizational religious activity will predict greater experience of "other-praising" emotions. 
•	Higher levels of intrinsic religiosity will predict greater experience of "other-praising" emotions. 
•	Greater frequency of organizational religious activity will predict higher reported gratefulness to God. 

Individual Differences and Gratitude Toward God:
•	Greater frequency of non-organizational religious activity will predict higher reported gratefulness to God. 
•	Higher levels of intrinsic religiosity will predict higher reported gratefulness to God. 

Prosocial Behavior:
•	Participants in the GTG condition will display higher frequencies in prosocial donation behavior than participants in all other conditions.
•	Participants in the gratitude conditions will display higher frequencies in prosocial donation compared to the control condition.
•	Higher levels of organizational religious activity will predict higher frequencies of prosocial donation behavior.
•	Higher levels of non-organizational religious activity will predict higher frequencies of prosocial donation behavior.
•	Higher levels of intrinsic religiosity will predict higher frequencies of prosocial donation behavior.
•	Participants in the GTG condition will donate higher amounts of money to a charity than participants in all other conditions.  
•	Participants in all the gratitude conditions will donate more money compared to those in the non-gratitude Control condition.
•	Higher levels of organizational religious activity will predict higher amounts of money donated to a charity.
•	Higher levels or non-organizational religious activity will predict higher amounts of money donated to a charity.
•	Higher levels or intrinsic religiosity will predict higher amounts of money donated to a charity.

question.value:
We plan to manipulate the type of gratitude expressed using six gratitude conditions: gratitude to God, gratitude to people, gratitude to parents, gratitude to country, general gratitude, and a control condition. Below are the condition prompts: 

•	Gratitude toward God: “We are interested in people’s experiences of gratitude toward God. Please write down anything for which you are grateful or thankful to God for giving you. Please list only one thing per line. You may list as many or as few things as you would like.”

•	Gratitude toward Country: “We are interested in people’s experiences of gratitude toward their country. Please write down anything for which you are grateful or thankful to your country for giving you. Please list only one thing per line. You may list as many or as few things as you would like.”

•	General gratitude: “We are interested in people’s experiences of gratitude. Please write down anything for which you are grateful or thankful. Please list only one thing per line. You may list as many or as few things as you would like.” 

•	Gratitude toward People: “We are interested in people’s experiences of gratitude toward other people. Please write down anything for which you are grateful or thankful to other people for giving you. Please list only one thing per line. You may list as many or as few things as you would like.”

•	Gratitude toward Parents: “We are interested in people’s experiences of gratitude toward the countries they live in. Think about the country that you currently live in. Please write down anything for which you are grateful or thankful to your country for giving you. Please list only one thing per line. You may list as many or as few things as you would like.”

•	Control: “We are interested in people's experiences in their daily lives. Please write down your daily routine, starting from when you wake up in the morning. Please list only one thing per line. You may list as many or as few things as you would like.”

In addition to collecting demographic information from all participants (e.g., age, sex, race, religious affiliation), we will also ask them to complete a series of psychological questionnaires. These will include: 
•	Positive and Negative Affect Schedule including additional expansive emotions (PANAS; adapted from Watson et al., 1988)
•	Expansive emotions (elevation, gratitude, admiration, awe, and compassion) added to the PANAS (Algoe & Haidt, 2009; Stellar et al., 2017)
•	Gratitude toward God (Krause, 2006) 
•	Duke University Religion Index (DUREL; Koenig & Bussing, 2010)
•	Donation Opportunity (Ratchford & Al-Kire, 2020)

Validated scale items will be scored according to the methods by which they were validated. However, we will also check the factor analysis structure to ensure they hold for the present population. 

We will also create a coding scheme to analyze the quantity and type of things participants are grateful for in each condition, as well as to whom they are grateful for each thing listed. A more detailed description of this coding plan can be found below, under "Transformations."
We will utilize the following statistical models, appropriate to each specific hypothesis: ANCOVA, ANOVA, MANOVA, and linear regression models.

q20.value:
To address our research questions, we will use both qualitative (e.g., content analysis) and quantitative methodology. Participants will provide condition-specific answers to free-response questions designed to assess the quantity and content of things participants were grateful for (e.g, “We are interested in people’s experiences of gratitude toward God. Please write down anything for which you are grateful or thankful to God for giving you… you may list as many or as few things as you would like”) and to whom participants were grateful (e.g., “For each thing you listed, please indicate to who or what you are specifically grateful to”). 

Initial themes will be identified from the content of the free-response questions. To do this, researchers will read individual responses and code how many things participants were grateful for (quantity of items listed), what participants are grateful for (e.g., transcendent vs. materialistic vs. abstract items), and to whom participants are grateful  (e.g., specific person vs. abstract identity vs. general feelings of gratitude). Researchers will first define each category and will then construct a preliminary codebook for all free-response items.  Appropriateness of the definitions will be confirmed by having two research assistants randomly read responses within each question, confirm the categories, and provide feedback on the definition. Following feedback from the other research assistants, categories and definitions will be refined and finalized. 

Then, two research assistants will code responses to all condition-specific free response answers in SPSS by indicating the presence (1) or absence (0) of a category for each question answered by a participant. If varied participant responses occur, multiple categories relevant to the response may be assigned to a single answer. Interrater reliability will be calculated by having two individual coders code a random sample to 50 responses for each question. Finally, researchers will calculate frequencies to identify the most common categories within each condition-specific question.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the ANCOVA, ANOVA, MANOVA, and regression models suggest that results are statistically significant from those expected if the null hypothesis(es) were correct.

q22.value: Data will be excluded if the participant fails the two attention checks or has a repeating IP address. Outliers will be included in the analyses and be noted as such.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete all measures, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: Examining the effect of acute psychological stress on endurance capabilities in females

q1.value: Examining the effect of acute psychological stress on endurance capabilities in females

q3.value:
An acute psychological stressor, such as in a public speaking task, initiates a complex physiological stress response. Research guided by the Biopsychosocial Model (BPSM) framework has shown that when individuals respond to a task with a threat appraisal, their performance in physical tasks is reduced compared to individuals who respond with a challenge appraisal. The majority of the physical tasks were comprised of spatial, cognitive, tactical, and motor skills, while only one study under the BPSM framework assessed endurance exercise. Importantly, these studies only examine threat and challenge using a measure of cardiovascular reactivity to a task-related prompt. Research in mental fatigue supports the hypothesis that endurance exercise may be affected by task-unrelated psychological processes, similar to those which initiate physiological threat or challenge responses. To date, there is no evidence that assesses how the physiological stress response, both in terms of cardiovascular reactivity and HPA axis activation, following a task-unrelated psychological stressor affects endurance exercise performance. 
Therefore, the primary objective of the proposed experimental study is to investigate whether an acute psychological stressor impedes physical performance, measured by power output, during a subsequent endurance exercise task, an 8KM time trial, in a healthy but untrained sample of females during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. The secondary objective of the proposed experiment is to complete a comprehensive examination of psychological (i.e., perceptions of exertion, mood, arousal) and physiological (i.e., oxygen consumption, heart rate, and cortisol response to the time trial) differences during and after the 8KM time trial in response to the acute psychological stressor and placebo stressor, respectively.

q4.value:
The primary hypothesis of the proposed study is that exposure to a laboratory-induced psychological stressor will reduce performance in the time trial, operationalized as a decrease in average power output and power output trajectories, compared to a time trial performed following a placebo task.
The secondary hypothesis of the proposed study is that participants will report elevated perceptions of exertions, both average values and trajectories, during the time trial that immediately follows the TSST, compared to the time trial which follows the P-TSST.
I hypothesize that participants’ average oxygen consumption and oxygen consumption trajectory will be lower during the time trial following the TSST, relative to the time trial immediately following the P-TSST. The proposed study will also test the secondary hypothesis that exposure to the TSST will result in an attenuated cortisol response to the time trial, compared to exposure to the P-TSST.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: True experimental, randomized between subjects design with one factor (acute psychological stressor) and 2 levels (trier social stress test & placebo).

q9.value: The proposed study will use block randomization, with a block size of 2. Participants will be assigned to one of the two equally sized blocks that represent the two levels of the independent variable. A study coordinator that is not involved in testing will oversee randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Please see attached documents for details regarding inclusion and exclusion criteria, as well as recruitment procedure.
Participants will be paid $40 for participating in the study, provided in 2 payments for participating in each day of the study ($10 for day 1, $30 for day 2). Participants will also be provided with the results of their time trial as well as with an interpretation of their physiological fitness data. 
Participants will be contacted to confirm eligibility and schedule visits based on the order in which they provided their contact information. Participants will be scheduled until the sample size of 90 has been satisfied.

q13.value: 90 participants will be randomized in the proposed study. Participants must attend both days of the study to be randomized.

q14.value: Based on an a priori power analysis for an ANOVA calculated using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007), the sample for the proposed study is required to be at least 90 participants to detect a medium effect size (0.3) at an α level of 0.05 with a test power of .80.

question.value: The independent variable has two levels: trier social stress test and placebo trier social stress test. Please see attached documents for details regarding operational definitions of these conditions.
Please see attached documents for details regarding operational definitions of all measured variables.

Chronic stress score will be based on the 10-item perceived stress scale. Responses to the four positively stated items (4,5,6,8) will be reverse coded and then all items will be summed to provide a chronic stress score.
Body Mass Index (BMI) will be calculated as participants weight over the square of their height (kg/m2)
Negative Affect will be calculated as the sum of the 10 item scale. Rumination scores will be expressed as the sum of the 4 item scale. Task appraisal will be calculated using the instructions stated in the attached document.

data.name: Task Appraisal Measure items and scoring.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Task Appraisal Measure items and scoring.pdf

question.value:
Two statistical models will be used in order to analyze group differences in mean and peak values, as well as group differences between trajectories of values throughout the time trial.
	A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will be used to analyze the differences in power output during the time trial, rating of perceived exertion during the time trial, and cortisol response to the time trial. 
Latent growth curve modelling will be conducted to examine differences in the trajectory of power output and rating of perceived exertion over 8 time points (8x1KM bins), with 2 levels. Individual measurements over time will be treated as level 1 observations, and between-person measurements are treated as level 2 data. Modelling will begin with just experimental group as the time-invariant predictor, and subsequent models may include other variables based on t-tests or chi-squared analyses. 
Descriptives (e.g., age, body mass index, menstrual phase, chronic stress) will be analysed for between group differences. If there are significant differences, subsequent modelling will include these variables.

q20.value:
Before data is analysed, we will test dependent variables for skewness, kurtosis. If data is not normally distributed, then we will apply a log transformation (for zero values, a value of .0001 will be substituted so log transformation doesn’t result in an infinite value). Randomized groups will be dummy coded with two letters (X and Y) to blind the person performing analysis to the group. Model diagnostics will be performed based on fitted values and residuals.
For exploratory analysis, cortisol reactivity to the stressor will be dummy coded based on a median split, with a value of 1 being assigned to participants who respond greater than or equal to the median, and a value of 0 being assigned to participants who respond less than the median.

q21.value:
The proposed study will use an alpha level of .05 to determine whether findings are significant. 
For exploratory analyses, an alpha level of .1 will be used to determine whether findings warrant further examination.

q22.value:
Failure to complete or comply with the procedures for the Trier Social Stress Test or the Time Trial will result in complete omission of the participant's data.
Outliers will be included, unless entry error is obvious (data with a magnitude over 10 times the mean)

q23.value: If data is missing either at random or complete at random, then multiple imputation will be used. To perform multiple imputation, the missRanger function from the r package missRanger will be used. To allow for reproducibility, the default function parameters as well as set.seed will be used.

q24.value:
Using the same statistical models as described above, exploratory analyses will include investigating the effects of stressor condition (experimental group) on heart rate, heart rate variability, oxygen consumption, mood, and arousal during the time trial (average, peak, and trajectories). 
Exploratory analyses will also include investigating the effect of the TSST on pre-post comparisons of negative affect and task appraisal, and post-TSST measures of rumination.
As a greater cortisol response would be indicative of a successful threat manipulation during the acute laboratory stressor as well as a proxy of the challenge-threat index, the proposed study will also explore whether individuals’ cortisol reactivity to the stressor predicts the above performance differences (i.e., power output) and responses to exercise (i.e., perceptions of exertion, cortisol response) during the time trial.

registration_responses.q1: Examining the effect of acute psychological stress on endurance capabilities in females
registration_responses.q3:
An acute psychological stressor, such as in a public speaking task, initiates a complex physiological stress response. Research guided by the Biopsychosocial Model (BPSM) framework has shown that when individuals respond to a task with a threat appraisal, their performance in physical tasks is reduced compared to individuals who respond with a challenge appraisal. The majority of the physical tasks were comprised of spatial, cognitive, tactical, and motor skills, while only one study under the BPSM framework assessed endurance exercise. Importantly, these studies only examine threat and challenge using a measure of cardiovascular reactivity to a task-related prompt. Research in mental fatigue supports the hypothesis that endurance exercise may be affected by task-unrelated psychological processes, similar to those which initiate physiological threat or challenge responses. To date, there is no evidence that assesses how the physiological stress response, both in terms of cardiovascular reactivity and HPA axis activation, following a task-unrelated psychological stressor affects endurance exercise performance. 
Therefore, the primary objective of the proposed experimental study is to investigate whether an acute psychological stressor impedes physical performance, measured by power output, during a subsequent endurance exercise task, an 8KM time trial, in a healthy but untrained sample of females during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. The secondary objective of the proposed experiment is to complete a comprehensive examination of psychological (i.e., perceptions of exertion, mood, arousal) and physiological (i.e., oxygen consumption, heart rate, and cortisol response to the time trial) differences during and after the 8KM time trial in response to the acute psychological stressor and placebo stressor, respectively.
registration_responses.q4:
The primary hypothesis of the proposed study is that exposure to a laboratory-induced psychological stressor will reduce performance in the time trial, operationalized as a decrease in average power output and power output trajectories, compared to a time trial performed following a placebo task.
The secondary hypothesis of the proposed study is that participants will report elevated perceptions of exertions, both average values and trajectories, during the time trial that immediately follows the TSST, compared to the time trial which follows the P-TSST.
I hypothesize that participants’ average oxygen consumption and oxygen consumption trajectory will be lower during the time trial following the TSST, relative to the time trial immediately following the P-TSST. The proposed study will also test the secondary hypothesis that exposure to the TSST will result in an attenuated cortisol response to the time trial, compared to exposure to the P-TSST.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q9: The proposed study will use block randomization, with a block size of 2. Participants will be assigned to one of the two equally sized blocks that represent the two levels of the independent variable. A study coordinator that is not involved in testing will oversee randomization.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: 90 participants will be randomized in the proposed study. Participants must attend both days of the study to be randomized.
registration_responses.q14: Based on an a priori power analysis for an ANOVA calculated using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007), the sample for the proposed study is required to be at least 90 participants to detect a medium effect size (0.3) at an α level of 0.05 with a test power of .80.
registration_responses.q20:
Before data is analysed, we will test dependent variables for skewness, kurtosis. If data is not normally distributed, then we will apply a log transformation (for zero values, a value of .0001 will be substituted so log transformation doesn’t result in an infinite value). Randomized groups will be dummy coded with two letters (X and Y) to blind the person performing analysis to the group. Model diagnostics will be performed based on fitted values and residuals.
For exploratory analysis, cortisol reactivity to the stressor will be dummy coded based on a median split, with a value of 1 being assigned to participants who respond greater than or equal to the median, and a value of 0 being assigned to participants who respond less than the median.
registration_responses.q21:
The proposed study will use an alpha level of .05 to determine whether findings are significant. 
For exploratory analyses, an alpha level of .1 will be used to determine whether findings warrant further examination.
registration_responses.q22:
Failure to complete or comply with the procedures for the Trier Social Stress Test or the Time Trial will result in complete omission of the participant's data.
Outliers will be included, unless entry error is obvious (data with a magnitude over 10 times the mean)
registration_responses.q23: If data is missing either at random or complete at random, then multiple imputation will be used. To perform multiple imputation, the missRanger function from the r package missRanger will be used. To allow for reproducibility, the default function parameters as well as set.seed will be used.
registration_responses.q24:
Using the same statistical models as described above, exploratory analyses will include investigating the effects of stressor condition (experimental group) on heart rate, heart rate variability, oxygen consumption, mood, and arousal during the time trial (average, peak, and trajectories). 
Exploratory analyses will also include investigating the effect of the TSST on pre-post comparisons of negative affect and task appraisal, and post-TSST measures of rumination.
As a greater cortisol response would be indicative of a successful threat manipulation during the acute laboratory stressor as well as a proxy of the challenge-threat index, the proposed study will also explore whether individuals’ cortisol reactivity to the stressor predicts the above performance differences (i.e., power output) and responses to exercise (i.e., perceptions of exertion, cortisol response) during the time trial.

registration_responses.q8.question: True experimental, randomized between subjects design with one factor (acute psychological stressor) and 2 levels (trier social stress test & placebo).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Please see attached documents for details regarding inclusion and exclusion criteria, as well as recruitment procedure.
Participants will be paid $40 for participating in the study, provided in 2 payments for participating in each day of the study ($10 for day 1, $30 for day 2). Participants will also be provided with the results of their time trial as well as with an interpretation of their physiological fitness data. 
Participants will be contacted to confirm eligibility and schedule visits based on the order in which they provided their contact information. Participants will be scheduled until the sample size of 90 has been satisfied.
registration_responses.q16.question: The independent variable has two levels: trier social stress test and placebo trier social stress test. Please see attached documents for details regarding operational definitions of these conditions.
registration_responses.q17.question: Please see attached documents for details regarding operational definitions of all measured variables.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Chronic stress score will be based on the 10-item perceived stress scale. Responses to the four positively stated items (4,5,6,8) will be reverse coded and then all items will be summed to provide a chronic stress score.
Body Mass Index (BMI) will be calculated as participants weight over the square of their height (kg/m2)
Negative Affect will be calculated as the sum of the 10 item scale. Rumination scores will be expressed as the sum of the 4 item scale. Task appraisal will be calculated using the instructions stated in the attached document.

q18.uploader.file_name: Task Appraisal Measure items and scoring.pdf

registration_responses.q19.question:
Two statistical models will be used in order to analyze group differences in mean and peak values, as well as group differences between trajectories of values throughout the time trial.
	A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will be used to analyze the differences in power output during the time trial, rating of perceived exertion during the time trial, and cortisol response to the time trial. 
Latent growth curve modelling will be conducted to examine differences in the trajectory of power output and rating of perceived exertion over 8 time points (8x1KM bins), with 2 levels. Individual measurements over time will be treated as level 1 observations, and between-person measurements are treated as level 2 data. Modelling will begin with just experimental group as the time-invariant predictor, and subsequent models may include other variables based on t-tests or chi-squared analyses. 
Descriptives (e.g., age, body mass index, menstrual phase, chronic stress) will be analysed for between group differences. If there are significant differences, subsequent modelling will include these variables.

attributes.title: Gesture use, familiarity and aging
attributes.description: This project contains a template and instructions for registering a research project that uses an existing dataset.

q1.value: The effect of age and familiarity on gesture use within a collaborative learning setting

q2.value: James Shuffley, Ellen Davidson, Sarah E. MacPherson, Catherine J Crompton

q3.value: Research has shown gesture use is beneficial to human communication and learning in children. However, to date, there is little research into the effect of aging on gesture use and the few studies reported in the literature have not investigated gesture use in a collaborative learning setting. The current study looks to build upon data collected during previous research and investigate what effects age and familiarity have on gesture use, as well as the effect gesture use has on both immediate and delayed performance in a collaborative learning task.

q4.value:
Older adults will not significantly differ in their proportional number of gestures compared to younger adults.
Older adults will use fewer representational gestures compared to younger adults.

Familiarity will not influence the proportional number of gestures used by older and younger adults
Familiarity will not influence the type of gestures used by older and younger adults 

Gesture frequency will significantly influence immediate recall performance on the collaborative learning task 
Gesture frequency will significantly influence delayed recall performance on the collaborative learning task

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The original study was comprised of a between- and within-subject repeated measures design. Young and Old participants completed a map task with a partner who was either familiar (a friend or family member) or unfamiliar (a stranger) and then completed a second map task with someone from the opposite familiarity condition to that which they began. The familiarity condition was counterbalanced. The current study uses data from this previous research which will be coded for gesture use and type. Gesture frequency and type will be considered proportional to the overall length of interaction. Therefore, the gesture variable is calculated as the number of gestures (either total, representational, or non-representational) divided by the time taken to complete the trial (seconds).

See attached file for the preregistration document.

q9.value: The original study randomly assigned participants to each familiarity condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Gesture data has been coded using the DoSaGE coding scheme. The data has been cleaned and sorted into data sets but has not been studied or analysed beyond this.

question.value:
•	Twelve younger adults (recruited through the University of Edinburgh MyCareerHub website) and 12 older adult participants (recruited through the University of Edinburgh volunteer panel).
•	Each participant was required to take a familiar same-aged partner to the testing session (total of 24 younger and 24 older participants).
•	Each of the pairs knew each other as a partner, spouse, sibling or friend for at least 2 years and spoke to one another at least once a week.
•	Younger adults (18 female)
•	Older adults (14 female)
•	Participants only completed the task with someone in the same age group (younger or older). All participants completed the task twice, once with their familiar partner and once with an unfamiliar partner. The familiarity condition was counter-balanced between groups of participants.
•	The sessions included the experimental task, as well as background neuropsychological tests and lasted approximately 90 minutes. Participants were remunerated for their time.

q13.value: The existing data set has 48 participants.

q14.value: The sample size of the current study is constrained by that of the original study.

question.value: N/A

Gesture
Overall frequency and type of gestures used. Coded with DoSaGE coding scheme. The gesture types will be grouped into representational (Iconic, Metaphoric, Diectic and Emblem) vs. non-representational (Beat and Non-identifiable). Gesture frequency and type will be considered proportional to the overall length of interaction. Therefore, the gesture variable is calculated as the number of gestures (either total, representational, or non-representational) divided by the time taken to complete the trial (seconds).

Task performance
Performance on the collaborative task includes two variables, each out of a total of 36: immediate recall as assessed immediately following the task, and delayed recall at one week.
N/A

To determine the effect of age and familiarity on overall gesture usage, a repeated measures analysis of variance will be used. The categorical independent variables are age and familiarity and the dependent variable is the overall proportional frequency of gestures

To determine the effect of age and familiarity on gesture type use, a repeated measures analysis of variance will be used. The categorical independent variables are age, familiarity and gesture type and the dependent variable if the proportional frequency of gesture type. 

To determine the effect of gesture use on learning performance, a multiple linear regression will be used. The first model will have the independent variables of overall proportional gesture frequency + age, and the dependent variable of map task performance score. The second model will add familiarity to the model. We will assess if there is a significant improvement in model fit, and if so, familiarity will be kept in the model for subsequent interaction analysis, if not it will be removed. The third model will assess the interaction between gesture use and age (and possibly familiarity if it improved model fit). This model will have the independent variables of gesture frequency + age (and familiarity) and interaction of gesture * age with the dependent variable of map task performance score.

q20.value: Box-Cox transformations to normalise negative skewness.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining whether the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. An FDR correction will be used to control for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
•	Data from videos which were corrupted/unable to play will be excluded.
•	Data from participants who are not visible in the video will be excluded.

q23.value:
One corrupted/missing video, and one video which only shows one participant (it cuts off 	the other, so we are unable to see their gestures).

The performance data for the delayed recall task has 8 cases of missing data for the young group as a result of participants not returning. In order to maximise statistical power, we have imputed the mean score for the younger group on the delayed recall task for the missing data cases.

attributes.title: A Pseudo-Randomised Control Trial of the Benefits of "Body Image in the Digital Age" Teacher Training on Trainee Teachers' Body Image, and Social Media Literacy

q1.value: A pseudo-randomised control trial of the benefits of "Body Image in the Digital Age" Teacher Training on Trainee Teachers' Body Image and Social Media Literacy

q3.value:
The purpose of the research is to examine how participation in "Body Image in the Digital Age" teacher training impacts trainee teachers' body image and social media literacy.

Trainee teachers  will be pseudo-randomly assigned to either a [1] Experimental condition who participate in a three hour "Body Image in the Digital Age" teacher training programme immediately post baseline data collection or [2] Waiting list control condition who receive the same training after the study has completed. 

Participants will complete measures of body image (body satisfaction, body talk, thin ideal internalisation and self-objectification) and social media literacy at baseline and six-eight weeks later. A sub-sample of participants will be invited to take part in interviews after data collection is complete to further explore some of the ways in which the training session has impacted their own personal well-being, as well as their teaching practice.

q4.value: H1: Participants in the experimental group will report higher post-intervention body image and social media literacy than the control group (when controlling for pre-intervention levels of these constructs).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
2 x 2 mixed design. RM variable = Time (i.e., Time 1 v. Time 2) and IG variable = Condition (i.e., receives training v. waiting list control. Also, qualitative interviews with a small sub-sample of participants.

Teachers attended a 3 hour training session on how to deliver the Body Image in the Digital Age school intervention. Participants were recruited via email from course leaders and provided with a list of available training sessions. They were allocated to sessions on a first come, first served basis.
 
After quantitative data collection is complete, participants will be invited to attend an interview. In the interview, they will be asked (1) about their thoughts about the training, (2) how they feel their thoughts about their body /social media behaviour have changed since the training - and - (3) how the feel it has influenced their classroom practice in relation to these issues.

q9.value: Participants were provided with a list of dates on which training was available and then asked to state which sessions they could attend. They were then assigned to a training session by a research assistant depending on the remaining places left for the session (i.e., the session with the fewest delegates at the time their email stating their availability was received). This was performed by a research assistant who had no prior knowledge of the participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data collection is still ongoing. More specifically, training sessions and recruitment are still actively ongoing. Interviews have not yet been conducted.

question.value: Trainee teachers enrolled on teacher training programmes at UK universities  (this is the only eligibility requirement). Participants will be recruited through emails sent by the course leader/other appropriate point of contact. Participants of all age/genders/ethnic groups are permitted to participate. Participants will receive no payment for participation but will receive a training pack/CPD certificate.

Condition: In the experimental condition, participants will receive the standardised "Body Image in the Digital Age" teacher training programme (see below). Training lasts three hours and is delivered by two experienced BIDA trainers. In the waiting list control, they will not receive this training until after they have completed both questionnaires for this study.

Social Media Literacy -  [Adapted from Simons, M., Meeus, W., & T'Sas, J. (2017). Measuring Media Literacy for Media Education: Development of a Questionnaire for Teachers' Competencies. Journal of Media Literacy Education, 9(1), 99-115.]

Body Appreciation - [Tylka, T. L., & Wood-Barcalow, N. L. (2015). The Body Appreciation Scale-2: item refinement and psychometric evaluation. Body image, 12, 53-67.]

Thin Ideal Internalization. [Schaefer, L. M., Burke, N. L., Thompson, J. K., Dedrick, R. F., Heinberg, L. J., Calogero, R. M., ... & Anderson, D. A. (2015). Development and validation of the Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance Questionnaire-4 (SATAQ-4). Psychological Assessment, 27(1), 54.]

Body Satisfaction Scale. [Bird, E. L., Halliwell, E., Diedrichs, P. C., & Harcourt, D. (2013). Happy Being Me in the UK: A controlled evaluation of a school-based body image intervention with pre-adolescent children. Body Image, 10(3), 326-334. http://dx.doi.org.yorksj.idm.oclc.org/10.1016/j.bodyim.2013.02.008]

Off- and On-line Body Talk Engagement. Four questions adapted from [Salk, R. H., & Engeln-Maddox, R. registration_responses.q1: A pseudo-randomised control trial of the benefits of "Body Image in the Digital Age" Teacher Training on Trainee Teachers' Body Image and Social Media Literacy
registration_responses.q3:
The purpose of the research is to examine how participation in "Body Image in the Digital Age" teacher training impacts trainee teachers' body image and social media literacy.

Trainee teachers  will be pseudo-randomly assigned to either a [1] Experimental condition who participate in a three hour "Body Image in the Digital Age" teacher training programme immediately post baseline data collection or [2] Waiting list control condition who receive the same training after the study has completed. 

Participants will complete measures of body image (body satisfaction, body talk, thin ideal internalisation and self-objectification) and social media literacy at baseline and six-eight weeks later. A sub-sample of participants will be invited to take part in interviews after data collection is complete to further explore some of the ways in which the training session has impacted their own personal well-being, as well as their teaching practice.
registration_responses.q4: H1: Participants in the experimental group will report higher post-intervention body image and social media literacy than the control group (when controlling for pre-intervention levels of these constructs).

This was performed by a research assistant who had no prior knowledge of the participants.

Participants were recruited via email from course leaders and provided with a list of available training sessions. They were allocated to sessions on a first come, first served basis.
 
After quantitative data collection is complete, participants will be invited to attend an interview. In the interview, they will be asked (1) about their thoughts about the training, (2) how they feel their thoughts about their body /social media behaviour have changed since the training - and - (3) how the feel it has influenced their classroom practice in relation to these issues.

q4.value:
H1. Participants in Group A, who are informed that their gameplay is screen captured will be more accurate in the Recall Task and the Sequence Task, compared to participants in Group B, who are uninformed that their gameplay is screen captured. However, responses between Group A and Group B will not differ to a statistically significant degree on the Rating Task and the Experience Task. 
	H2.  Unlike participants in Group B, participants in Group A Time 1 responses will not differ from Group A Time 2 responses to a statistically significant degree on the Recall Task and Sequence Task.  In comparison, both Group A and Group B Time 2 responses on the Rating Task and Experience Task will differ from Time 1. If participants are motivated to view their behavior as justified, then participants may view the scene as more dangerous after review compared to before review. 
	H3. Group C responses will not be statistically significantly different from Group A and responses at Time 2.
	H4. There will be a greater difference between Group A Time 1 responses and Group C responses than within Group A Time 1 and Group A Time 2 responses. This is because writing down responses before review will anchor participants responses to some extent.

q4.value:
H1: Participant’s responses to officer credibility and trust in the officer will not differ depending on whether or not the officer pre-reviewed the footage.
H2: Participants who learn that there were discrepancies between the officer’s statement and BWC footage will judge the officer as less credible but the warning will mitigate this effect.
H3: There will be a significant interaction between the stressfulness of the encounter manipulation, implicit theory memory scale, and consistency. People with more memory skepticism will be more trusting of the officer when the encounter is stressful and there are inconsistencies. 
H4: Officer and civilian responses will mostly align except officers will be more trusting of an officer who has a statement that is inconsistent with the footage. Officer and civilian responses will align more closely for people who score high on the identification with police measure. 
H5: Participants will be less trustworthy of a statement that is inconsistent with the footage when the officer is on trial for his actions.

Opening statement: Police departments are adopting the use of body worn cameras across the United States. These cameras are used to record incidents in real time and the resulting video can be downloaded for review. One question emerging with respect to body worn camera policies is when officers should review their body camera video, if at all. Specifically, if officers have the option of reviewing police video should they review their video (a) before producing their written statement or (b) only after they have produced their written statement? This survey is designed to better understand people’s attitudes and beliefs regarding body camera video-review policy.

1.	Before providing any statement about an incident, officers should review any available body worn camera video of the incident.  
2.	Officer memories for incidents should be similar to body worn camera video recorded during the incident. 
3.	Differences between an officer’s statement and their body worn camera video is likely a sign of deceit. 
4.	Differences between an officer’s statement and their body worn camera video is likely a sign that officers conspired to create a story about what happened. 
5.	Officers should be able to review their body worn camera video before producing a statement for stressful events (i.e., events involving a physical confrontation and/or weapon). 
6.	Officers should be able to review their body worn camera video before producing a statement for less stressful events (i.e., events not involving a physical confrontation or weapon).
7.	Body worn camera video is more accurate than officers’ memories. 
8.	Officers’ statements will more accurately reflect what actually happened in an event after they review camera video.  
9.	Reviewing a body worn camera video of an event is likely to alter how an officer remembers the event. 
10.	Reviewing a body worn camera video will help officers remember more about what happened in an event. 
11.	Reviewing a body worn camera video of an event is likely to result in a statement that is consistent with the contents of the video but not the officer’s memory. 
12.	Officers will be able to differentiate between what they remember from an event and what was later seen in the body worn camera video.
13.	The public will distrust officers who review available body worn camera video footage before producing a statement.
14.	The public will distrust an officer’s statement if it is inconsistent with what the body worn camera video shows. 
15.	The public will distrust an officer’s statement if it perfectly matches what the body worn camera video shows.
16.	When statements and body worn camera video differ, legal decision-makers should default to what the video captured. 
17.	Body worn camera video is more objective than an officer’s memory.
18.	Body worn camera videos might sometimes fail to show what an officer perceived during an event.  
19.	Knowing exactly what happened during an event is more important than knowing what an officer perceived during an event.
20.	Police officers have better memory ability than members of the general public with no law enforcement training.
21.	Police officers’ memories are more reliable than members of the general public with no law enforcement training.
22.	 Police officers should write statements as soon as safely possible after an event has taken place. 
23.	Police officers’ memories are more accurate for stressful events (i.e., events involving a physical confrontation and/or weapon) than less stressful events (i.e., events not involving a physical confrontation and/or weapon). 
24.	Police statements are often unnecessary when body worn camera video is available.
25.	Because of limitations with the technology, body worn cameras might sometimes fail to capture the full scene. 
26.	When determining whether an officer’s use of force was appropriate, it’s most important to look at what was captured on body worn camera video rather than learning about the event from the officer’s statement. 
27.	When determining an officer’s use of force was appropriate, it’s important to bear in mind that the body worn camera video will not show how the officer perceived the event.

I will conduct an exploratory factor analysis to determine whether the 27-items that participants respond to are broken down into factors.
I will conduct ANOVAs to determine whether the participant group responses differ by factor. 
If I have large enough samples, I will determine whether demographic characteristics differ by factor.

H3: There will be a significant interaction between the stressfulness of the encounter manipulation, implicit theory memory scale, and consistency. People with more memory skepticism will be more trusting of the officer when the encounter is stressful and there are inconsistencies. 
H4: Officer and civilian responses will mostly align except officers will be more trusting of an officer who has a statement that is inconsistent with the footage. Officer and civilian responses will align more closely for people who score high on the identification with police measure. 
H5: Participants will be less trustworthy of a statement that is inconsistent with the footage when the officer is on trial for his actions.

q3.value:
消費増税の問題は、社会保障費が増大する中にあって極めて重要である。本研究は、政治的にも人々の生活にも大きな影響を及ぼす消費税の問題を対象に、消費税のもつ逆進性と消費税の使途が、人々の消費税に対する支持にいかなる影響を与えるのかをサーヴェイ実験の手法を用いて検証する。
消費税は広範な人々から徴収されるため、社会保障の有力な財源となるが、他方で、逆進的な性質をもっている。この意味で、社会保障の拡充は格差の縮小や平等化に寄与すると考えられると同時に、貧しい人々に負担感を与える両義性がある。したがって、特に平等を志向する傾向のある左派は、北欧型の福祉国家のように社会保障の拡充のために消費増税に賛成するか、それとも逆進性が与える負の影響を重視して消費増税に反対するかというジレンマに直面している。
また、右派や中道の有権者に対しては、ヨーロッパの福祉国家のように、消費税が普遍的な社会保障サーヴィスの財源となっている点に着目し、消費増税が逆進性をもち右派や中道にとり不利ではなく、普遍的な社会保障が相対的に豊かな人々のリスク回避にとっても望ましいものである可能性がある。

q4.value:
消費税の支持が、いかなるフレームの下増減するのかを税の逆進性と社会政策の普遍主義との関係から検証する。
仮説1．消費税の逆進性を意識させると、相対的に豊かな人々が多いと考えられる右派の支持が増え、反対に、相対的に貧しい人々が多いと考えられる左派の支持が減ると予想される。
仮説2．消費税を財源とした福祉政策の普遍性を意識させると、貧しい人々に対する再分配のみならず、豊かな人々にとってもリスクヘッジにもなるため、右派の支持が増え、反対に、貧しい人々に対する再分配を重視すべきと考える左派の支持が減ると予想される。

question.value:
実験ではまず被験者に消費税に関する説明⽂を表⽰し、それから消費税率についての意⾒を聞いた。実験群には6つのバージョンの説明⽂を⽤意して、ランダムに１つを割り当てた。まず、消費税の説明は全実験群に表示される（『』部は実験画⾯で太字）。
---
⽇本政府は、近年国家予算が増えている中で、『消費税の引き上げ』を⾏っています。消費税は、幅広い人々から徴収されるため、所得税や法⼈税に⽐べて、不景気のときにも税収が減りにくく、『安定した財源として期待できるから』です。
---
これに引き続いて、第2、3、5群には、以下のように消費税の逆進性を強調する文が表示される。
---
ただし、消費税には、『所得が低いほど負担感が大きくなる』という性質があります。消費税は、所得が高くても低くても、同じ価格の商品を買った場合には同じ税率で徴収されるからです。
---
第3、5群は、さらに引き続いて、普遍主義に関するランダマイズが以下のように提示される。
第3群
---
消費税が使われる対象の社会保障サービスは、『特に所得が低い人々にとって利益がある』と考えられています。
---
第5群
---
消費税が使われる対象の社会保障サービスは、『広く一般の人々にとって利益がある』と考えられています。
---
第4、6群は、消費税の逆進性に関する文が提示されずに、第3、5群が提示される順番になっている。

こうした文章を提示した後、消費税に対する選好を以下のように尋ねる。
---
日本における消費税の税率についてお聞きします。あなたは、日本において、『消費税は最終的に何％まで引き上げられる（引き下げられる）のが適切』だと思いますか。次のそれぞれの欄に、0から100までの半角数字で記入してください。わからない場合は999と記入してください。（ひとつだけ）

食料品などの生活必需品（現在は8％）	
その他すべての商品（現在は10％）

question.value: 調査対象者は、オンライン上のクラウドソーシングサービスであるランサーズの登録者プールから、１８歳以上を条件として募集した。三浦・⼩林 (2016) によれば、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者はネット調査のモニタに⽐べて、実験⽂や設問を読まないなど Satisficing と呼ばれる回答努⼒の最⼩限化 (Krosnick, 1991) を⾏いにくい。また、これまでの社会科学における実験で頻繁に利⽤されてきた⼤学⽣の実験参加者に⽐べて、⼈⼝統計、政治的⽴場、社会における位置付けなどの点から多様性が⾼いため、⼀般有権者の⾦融緩和政策選好についての実験を⾏う上で、より有⽤性が⾼いサンプルであると考えられる。ただし、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者は⽇本の有権者⼈⼝からランダムに抽出されたサンプルではない。したがって、実験のトリートメント効果を超えた調査回答の絶対値について解釈を⼀般化する際には留意が必要である。

二標本間のｔ検定、重回帰分析（最小二乗法、ロジット）を使用して分析を行う。以下は、各分析モデルの独立変数（IV）、従属変数（DV)、統制変数（CV）である。

①ｔ検定： IV=実験群＊イデオロギー、DV=消費税率（連続変数）
②最小二乗法：IV＝実験群＊イデオロギー、DV=消費税率（連続変数）、CV＝性別、年齢、収入、教育程度、仕事の有無、政治知識量（事実認識設問の合計）、内閣支持、経済学者信頼度、日本社会の平等認識、日本社会の同質性

イデオロギーは、次の3種類を使用する。
①自己申告イデオロギー　ideology
②政党支持イデオロギー　party_supp 自民公明日本維新を右派、立憲民主国民民主共産社民れいわ新選組を左派、その他無党派をどちらでもない
③争点イデオロギー　issue の変数を一因子で因子分析、因子スコアを使用。

registration_responses.q3:
消費増税の問題は、社会保障費が増大する中にあって極めて重要である。本研究は、政治的にも人々の生活にも大きな影響を及ぼす消費税の問題を対象に、消費税のもつ逆進性と消費税の使途が、人々の消費税に対する支持にいかなる影響を与えるのかをサーヴェイ実験の手法を用いて検証する。
消費税は広範な人々から徴収されるため、社会保障の有力な財源となるが、他方で、逆進的な性質をもっている。この意味で、社会保障の拡充は格差の縮小や平等化に寄与すると考えられると同時に、貧しい人々に負担感を与える両義性がある。したがって、特に平等を志向する傾向のある左派は、北欧型の福祉国家のように社会保障の拡充のために消費増税に賛成するか、それとも逆進性が与える負の影響を重視して消費増税に反対するかというジレンマに直面している。
また、右派や中道の有権者に対しては、ヨーロッパの福祉国家のように、消費税が普遍的な社会保障サーヴィスの財源となっている点に着目し、消費増税が逆進性をもち右派や中道にとり不利ではなく、普遍的な社会保障が相対的に豊かな人々のリスク回避にとっても望ましいものである可能性がある。
registration_responses.q4:
消費税の支持が、いかなるフレームの下増減するのかを税の逆進性と社会政策の普遍主義との関係から検証する。
仮説1．消費税の逆進性を意識させると、相対的に豊かな人々が多いと考えられる右派の支持が増え、反対に、相対的に貧しい人々が多いと考えられる左派の支持が減ると予想される。
仮説2．消費税を財源とした福祉政策の普遍性を意識させると、貧しい人々に対する再分配のみならず、豊かな人々にとってもリスクヘッジにもなるため、右派の支持が増え、反対に、貧しい人々に対する再分配を重視すべきと考える左派の支持が減ると予想される。

実験ではまず被験者に消費税に関する説明⽂を表⽰し、それから消費税率についての意⾒を聞いた。実験群には6つのバージョンの説明⽂を⽤意して、ランダムに１つを割り当てた。まず、消費税の説明は全実験群に表示される（『』部は実験画⾯で太字）。
---
⽇本政府は、近年国家予算が増えている中で、『消費税の引き上げ』を⾏っています。消費税は、幅広い人々から徴収されるため、所得税や法⼈税に⽐べて、不景気のときにも税収が減りにくく、『安定した財源として期待できるから』です。

これに引き続いて、第2、3、5群には、以下のように消費税の逆進性を強調する文が表示される。

---

消費税が使われる対象の社会保障サービスは、『広く一般の人々にとって利益がある』と考えられています。

attributes.title: Humor and Opinion Frames in Political Podcasts
attributes.description: The proposed experiment is part of a larger project seeking to categorize and assess the effectiveness of political podcasts on strengthening political attitudes and enhancing political knowledge. Prior to this outlined experimental testing, a first phase of content analysis was undertaken to determine which framing tactics are used most frequently in the most popular current affairs podcasts. The analysis found that two of the most popular framing tactics were humor and opinion. These two tactics will be compared with traditional hard news framing tactics in the proposed survey experiment, and the study will use a pro-attitudinal design in an attempt to recreate more realistic media consumption habits.

q1.value: Humor and Opinion Frames in Political Podcasts

q3.value: The proposed experiment is part of a larger project seeking to categorize and assess the effectiveness of political podcasts on strengthening political attitudes and enhancing political knowledge. Prior to this outlined experimental testing, a first phase of content analysis was undertaken to determine which framing tactics are used most frequently in the most popular current affairs podcasts. The analysis found that two of the most popular framing tactics were humor and opinion. These two tactics will be compared with traditional hard news framing tactics in the proposed survey experiment, and the study will use a pro-attitudinal design in an attempt to recreate more realistic media consumption habits.

q4.value:
RQ1: How successful is humor framing in strengthening political attitudes as compared to ‘hard news’ framing?
RQ2: How successful is opinion framing in strengthening political attitudes as compared to ‘hard news’ framing?
RQ3: How successful is humor framing in increasing political knowledge as compared to ‘hard news’ framing?
RQ4: How successful is opinion framing in increasing political knowledge as compared to hard news framing?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This survey experiment is composed of 4 minutes of survey questions and 90 seconds of audio (if the participant is randomly sorted into one of the first three treatment groups). The study is only seeking out United States citizens and will take approximately 5-6 minutes to complete.

In the pre-test phase, subjects will begin by reading provided IRB consent and disclosure forms and then clicking that they consent to be part of to the experiment. This disclosure section will make clear the need for subjects to take this survey on a device with audio player capability, and directly following the consent section, participants will be given an audio test to complete. In the attached audio there will be a stated four-digit number. Only with entry of that number (serving as an audio check), and with confirmation that they are a US citizen, will a participant be able to move forward. 

The final pre-test question asks participants about their views on government spending, and the aim of this question is to calculate people’s political leaning and already established attitude on government spending. Because the treatment in this experiment will involve a news story about a bill that seeks to spend public funds to fund school meals for America’s youth, it is important to measure where people stand on government spending prior to exposure to this treatment. That measured attitude will then be used to sort people into a more conservative leaning or liberal leaning pool, though their subsequent assignment to one of the four treatments will remain random.

After being sorted based on their measured political leanings, participants will be randomly assigned to one of four treatment groups (humor frames, punditry frames, hard news frames, and no audio treatment). Subjects in the first three treatment groups will be exposed to a 90 second audio clip about The Universal School Meals Program Act, a bill awaiting votes in the house and the senate that wants to provide free school meals to all children in American public schools. Treatment 1 involves a podcast clip revolving around this bill that is told with prevalent humor frames. Two different audio files have been created (one liberal leaning and one conservative) and while subjects will be randomly assigned to a treatment, they will be placed in either liberal or conservative groups based on their pre-stated views on government spending. Similarly, treatment 2 is composed of a podcast clip about this bill that is told with punditry and opinion frames. It also has two different audio files, one for liberal listeners, and one for conservative. Treatment 3, composed of hard news framing of this proposed policy, has only one audio clip, and finally treatment 4 consists of no audio clip. In treatment 4, participants will move directly from the pre-test to the post-test. 

Directly following whatever condition a participant was assigned to, study subjects will grade two questions on a seven point scale: Was the story clear? And, do you think the podcast contained false or misleading information? Following this, three knowledge questions that directly relate to the story will be asked. The intention in asking these stories is twofold: first, to see if participants were actively listening to the story, and second, to see if they learned anything from the story that members in the control group did not. They will then be asked questions about the importance of this school meals issue to the country, and whether they support the Universal School Meals Program Act having heard this podcast story clip. 

After giving their assessment on the story and the proposed policy, participants will be asked about their experiences with podcasts and political podcasts, how often they consume news media, and what American political parties they are likely to vote for. Through asking questions about their media consumption habits, how often they encounter podcasts, and what political parties they may be sympathetic towards, the hope is to have a more flushed out picture of what these participants bring bias-wise to the study. At this time, other important demographics like gender, race, age, and so on will be collected, using phrasing and flow mirroring Pew Research Center surveys, and a final comment section will be made available before the close of the survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Using MTurk to recruit 1500+ participants in my survey experiment. My population needs to be American citizens above the age of 18. All participants will be paid $0.80 for their time and for total completion of the study. There are a number of checks in place to make sure participants are actually accessing the test from inside the US.

q14.value: The total participant goal needed for each cell of these experiments is 385. Given that there are four treatment options in this experiment, the needed sample size is 1,540.

q15.value: There is no stopping rule in place, but paid participants will be limited based on the assigned budget of this research endeavor.

question.value:
Humor Frames. In treatment one, participants will be exposed to a 90 second podcast story that uses humor in its storytelling. They receive a baseline of facts that is shared between all three of the audio treatment groups, but those facts are cushioned with jokes and sarcasm aimed at engaging and entertaining the audience in a different way than hard news storytelling. The humor frames have been recreated in a liberal condition and a conservative one, and while the jokes are different, the relative level of humor is the same, with a comparable number of jokes and as much flow and tone mirroring as possible. 

Opinion Frames. In treatment two, participants will be exposed to a 90 second podcast story that uses opinion frames in its storytelling. There will be a baseline of facts that is shared between all three of the audio treatment groups, but those facts are supplemented with opinion and punditry provided by the speakers in the audio clip. This opinion is an entertainment and persuasion tactic that is more exaggerated than opinion-based statements are in hard news storytelling. The punditry frames have been recreated in a liberal condition and a conservative one, and while the opinions are different, the relative amount of time dedicated to opinions, and much of the flow and tone are as closely identical as possible.

Hard News Frames. In treatment three, participants will be exposed to a 90 second podcast story that is based off of a typical hard news style. The baseline facts shared in all of the audio treatments will be available in this podcast clip as well, but those facts are elaborated and more detail is provided. The goal in this treatment was to limit bias in storytelling, and as such both liberal and conservative opinion have been mentioned and presented, but the podcast clip itself is meant to inform and not to persuade. There is only one hard news audio clip, as liberal and conservative viewpoints should still operate from the same pool of quantifiable facts and figures.

See attached appendixes of pre and post testing for a more comprehensive list of measured variables. 

Pre-existing attitude on government spending. This variable will be measured in the pre-test with a question about government spending modeled after similar questions posed by ANES. 

Pre-existing attitude on USMPA. This variable will be measured in the pre-test with a question about support for the Universal School Meals Program Act . The same question will be asked in an identical way in the post-test.

Pre-existing political preference. This variable will be measured with a question about what political parties participants are likely to vote for. On a scale of one to ten, assessments are made about Democrats, Republicans, Libertarians, and the Green party, and the highest score will be taken as the measure of political preference. If all parties are scored the same, the respondent will be labeled an independent. 

Political attitude on USMPA and strengthening of that attitude. This is being measured so it can be compared across testing groups but also analyzed in conjunction with a similar question in the pretest. Measures for attitude will be assessed based on two questions regarding participant perception of the importance of this issue to the country, and their support of the proposed bill. 

Political news use and exposure. This will be assessed in the post-test through a question asking how frequently respondents interact with political news. 

Podcast use and exposure. This will be assessed in the post-test through two questions asking how frequently respondents listen to podcasts and to political podcasts specifically. 

Political Knowledge.  Three questions will be posed to participants about facts learned in the three audio treatments. By comparing listeners from those treatments to participants in the control group, these questions provide insight into how much knowledge is gained through listening to these three styles of political news storytelling.

In order to make meaning from the collected data in this experiment, multiple analyses of variance (ANOVAs) will be necessary. Through assessing both between group variance and within group variance, the hope is to ascertain whether my independent variables have had any substantial effect on participants (MIT, “Laboratory in Visual Cognition,” 2008). This experiment has four potential treatment groups (humor frames, opinion frames, hard news frames, and no treatment), but has purposefully been kept limited and controlled in its design and scope. As such, ANOVA models can be used to compare the mean values collected during the experiment.  The purpose of assessing these means is to see what differences and discrepancies may have been measured as a result of the manipulated variables (Shikano, Bräuninger and Stoffel, 2012). 

As has been outlined previously in this preregistration document, two of my treatment groups (humor frames and opinion frames) actually consist of two levels, one liberal and one conservative. This project has been designed in this way for a number of reasons. First, there are a number of sub-research questions I am asking about any potential differences between the framing effects of conservative podcasts and liberal ones. Second, in order to study the phenomena of political podcasts in a way that mirrors todays polarized, high-choice environment, two different treatment levels were needed. This being the case, I will of course test first between these two levels within each group, seeing if any changes across my dependent variables exist based purely on political leaning. While I expect that there will not be any kind of overwhelming difference in effect rate, a difference in means statistical test, in this case a t-test, will be able to confirm or dispute that. If and when I am able to reach the conclusion that the effect rates have been similar, I will then begin my large analysis of variance.
 (See expanded plan in attached PDF)

registration_responses.q12.question: Using MTurk to recruit 1500+ participants in my survey experiment. My population needs to be American citizens above the age of 18. All participants will be paid $0.80 for their time and for total completion of the study. There are a number of checks in place to make sure participants are actually accessing the test from inside the US.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Humor Frames. In treatment one, participants will be exposed to a 90 second podcast story that uses humor in its storytelling. They receive a baseline of facts that is shared between all three of the audio treatment groups, but those facts are cushioned with jokes and sarcasm aimed at engaging and entertaining the audience in a different way than hard news storytelling. The humor frames have been recreated in a liberal condition and a conservative one, and while the jokes are different, the relative level of humor is the same, with a comparable number of jokes and as much flow and tone mirroring as possible. 

Opinion Frames. In treatment two, participants will be exposed to a 90 second podcast story that uses opinion frames in its storytelling. There will be a baseline of facts that is shared between all three of the audio treatment groups, but those facts are supplemented with opinion and punditry provided by the speakers in the audio clip. This opinion is an entertainment and persuasion tactic that is more exaggerated than opinion-based statements are in hard news storytelling. The punditry frames have been recreated in a liberal condition and a conservative one, and while the opinions are different, the relative amount of time dedicated to opinions, and much of the flow and tone are as closely identical as possible.

Hard News Frames. In treatment three, participants will be exposed to a 90 second podcast story that is based off of a typical hard news style. The baseline facts shared in all of the audio treatments will be available in this podcast clip as well, but those facts are elaborated and more detail is provided. The goal in this treatment was to limit bias in storytelling, and as such both liberal and conservative opinion have been mentioned and presented, but the podcast clip itself is meant to inform and not to persuade. There is only one hard news audio clip, as liberal and conservative viewpoints should still operate from the same pool of quantifiable facts and figures.
registration_responses.q17.question:
See attached appendixes of pre and post testing for a more comprehensive list of measured variables. 

Pre-existing attitude on government spending. This variable will be measured in the pre-test with a question about government spending modeled after similar questions posed by ANES. 

Pre-existing attitude on USMPA. This variable will be measured in the pre-test with a question about support for the Universal School Meals Program Act . The same question will be asked in an identical way in the post-test.

Pre-existing political preference. This variable will be measured with a question about what political parties participants are likely to vote for. On a scale of one to ten, assessments are made about Democrats, Republicans, Libertarians, and the Green party, and the highest score will be taken as the measure of political preference. If all parties are scored the same, the respondent will be labeled an independent. 

Political attitude on USMPA and strengthening of that attitude. This is being measured so it can be compared across testing groups but also analyzed in conjunction with a similar question in the pretest. Measures for attitude will be assessed based on two questions regarding participant perception of the importance of this issue to the country, and their support of the proposed bill. 

Political news use and exposure. This will be assessed in the post-test through a question asking how frequently respondents interact with political news. 

Podcast use and exposure. This will be assessed in the post-test through two questions asking how frequently respondents listen to podcasts and to political podcasts specifically. 

Political Knowledge.  Three questions will be posed to participants about facts learned in the three audio treatments. By comparing listeners from those treatments to participants in the control group, these questions provide insight into how much knowledge is gained through listening to these three styles of political news storytelling.
registration_responses.q19.question:
In order to make meaning from the collected data in this experiment, multiple analyses of variance (ANOVAs) will be necessary. Through assessing both between group variance and within group variance, the hope is to ascertain whether my independent variables have had any substantial effect on participants (MIT, “Laboratory in Visual Cognition,” 2008). This experiment has four potential treatment groups (humor frames, opinion frames, hard news frames, and no treatment), but has purposefully been kept limited and controlled in its design and scope. As such, ANOVA models can be used to compare the mean values collected during the experiment.  The purpose of assessing these means is to see what differences and discrepancies may have been measured as a result of the manipulated variables (Shikano, Bräuninger and Stoffel, 2012). 

As has been outlined previously in this preregistration document, two of my treatment groups (humor frames and opinion frames) actually consist of two levels, one liberal and one conservative. This project has been designed in this way for a number of reasons. First, there are a number of sub-research questions I am asking about any potential differences between the framing effects of conservative podcasts and liberal ones. Second, in order to study the phenomena of political podcasts in a way that mirrors todays polarized, high-choice environment, two different treatment levels were needed. This being the case, I will of course test first between these two levels within each group, seeing if any changes across my dependent variables exist based purely on political leaning. While I expect that there will not be any kind of overwhelming difference in effect rate, a difference in means statistical test, in this case a t-test, will be able to confirm or dispute that. If and when I am able to reach the conclusion that the effect rates have been similar, I will then begin my large analysis of variance.
 (See expanded plan in attached PDF)

q3.value: 戦後の天皇は、政治的な権限を奪われながらも、国民は天皇の発言に注目し続けている。天皇の発言は、政治性を帯びないように注意深く選択されているが、それにもかかわらず、政治的な含意をもつことが時にあり得る。戦後の平成の天皇（今の上皇）と今上天皇は、政治的なイデオロギーから考えるとリベラルだと見なされるが、これは天皇制という保守的な制度とは相容れない側面がある。天皇はこうした立場にあって発言をしているため、その発言内容の意図せざる二重性には注目されてしかるべきである。本研究は、こうした天皇の発言が表現の自由に対する人々の選好に与える影響をサーヴェイ実験の手法を用いて分析する。

q4.value:
本研究では、ヘイトスピーチと歴史文化に対するイベントを題材にし、実際の天皇の発言と組み合わせた実験刺激を用いて、表現の自由に対する人々の選好に天皇の発言が与える影響を分析する。
ヘイトスピーチと、たとえば、あいちトリエンナーレのようなイベントは、どちらも表現の自由と密接に関係しているが、イデオロギー的な側面から考えると、正反対の性質を帯びている。すなわち、ヘイトスピーチは、一般に右派（保守）が規制に反対し、左派（リベラル）が規制に賛成すると考えられるのに対し、あいちトリエンナーレのような表現に対しては、一般に左派（リベラル）が規制に反対し、右派（保守）が規制に賛成すると考えられる。まず、このようなテーマのフレームが表現の自由に与える影響を分析する。仮説は以下のようになる。

仮説1．ヘイトスピーチと歴史文化的イベントは、人々の表現の自由規制に反対の影響を与える。
ただし、どちらのテーマがより影響を受けるといった度合いの比較は、テーマ自体の対称性が完全に担保されていないため困難である。

これらに加えて、天皇の発言が表現の自由規制に与える影響を検証する。平成の天皇や今上天皇は、天皇制という歴史的な制度の中で、平和や平等といったリベラルな価値を訴え続けている。
こうした状況にあっては、天皇そのものに対する属人的な信頼と、天皇制という制度に対する信頼が区別して認識されていると考えられる。そして、こうした区別は、人々のイデオロギーとも関係していると考えられる。すなわち、左派（リベラル）は、天皇制という制度に対して、自由主義や平等主義といった観点や、戦前の天皇制を想起するため否定的だが、リベラルな発言をする天皇は支持している。その一方で、右派（保守）は、リベラルな発言を繰り返す天皇には否定的だが、天皇制という制度そのものは歴史的な観点から支持していると考えられる。したがって、以下のような仮説が検証される。

仮説2．左派（リベラル）は、リベラルな天皇という人を信頼し、右派（保守）は、天皇制という制度を信頼する

こうした仮説が支持され、天皇という人に対する信頼と、天皇制という制度に対する信頼が異なれば、天皇による実際の発言もイデオロギー的な観点から支持・不支持が決定されるはずである。リベラルな天皇の発言は左派（リベラル）が支持し、右派（保守）は支持しないと考えられる。これをテーマ設定と組み合わせると、以下のような仮説が検証される。

仮説3-1．言論の自由を支持するリベラルな天皇発言は、ヘイトスピーチ問題においては、右派（保守）が天皇の意図を誤解し、ヘイトスピーチへのお墨付きを得たと考え、ヘイトスピーチ規制反対を強める
仮説3-2．ただし、その発言の後に、朝鮮半島に対する天皇のリベラルな発言があると、規制反対が弱まる

仮説4．言論の自由を支持するリベラルな天皇発言は、歴史文化的イベントにおいては、左派（リベラル）が天皇の意見を支持し、過去の日本の歴史批判の規制反対を強める
仮説4-1.　さらに、その発言の後に、朝鮮半島に対する天皇のリベラルな発言があると、規制反対をさらに強める

テーマをランダマイズする文は以下のようになる。
---
⽇本では（①外国人に対する民族・人種差別的な言動・活動（ヘイトスピーチ／憎悪表現）が活発になっている問題を受けて、②日本の文化・歴史に対する否定的な表現を含む芸術作品が公営の施設・イベントで展示されていた問題を受けて、）公共の場所における表現の規制に関する議論が⾼まっています。あなたは、公共の場所における表現を政府・⾃治体が規制することに関してどのような意⾒をお持ちでしょうか。（ひとつだけ）
---
という質問に答えてもらい、
---
積極的に⾏われるべきである
必要があれば⾏われるべきである
⾏うべきか、⾏うべきでないか、どちらともいえない
できるだけ⾏われるべきではない
どんな場合であっても⾏われるべきではない
わからない
---
という選択肢を選んでもらい、その後に、発言をランダマイズする以下の群が続く。
---
あなたは、公共の場所における表現を政府・⾃治体が規制することに関して、（賛否）とお答えになりました。 この問題に対しては、様々な意⾒がありますが、（①政治・憲法学者の間では、言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基本であり、大変大切なことであると考えら／②現在の上皇陛下は、天皇として在位されていた時に「言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基礎であり大変大切なこと」（平成元年8月4日のお言葉）とお言葉を述べら／③現在の上皇陛下は、平成天皇だった時に「言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基本であり、大変大切なこと」とお言葉を述べられ、また「我が国が朝鮮半島の人々に多大の苦難を与えた一時期がありました。私は先年、このことにつき私の深い悲しみの気持ちを表明いたしました」（平成6年3月24日のお言葉）と）話されています。
---
この後に、もう一度質問を繰り返し、人々の態度変化を分析する。

question.value: 調査対象者は、オンライン上のクラウドソーシングサービスであるランサーズの登録者プールから、１８歳以上を条件として募集した。三浦・⼩林 (2016) によれば、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者はネット調査のモニタに⽐べて、実験⽂や設問を読まないなど Satisficing と呼ばれる回答努⼒の最⼩限化 (Krosnick, 1991) を⾏いにくい。また、これまでの社会科学における実験で頻繁に利⽤されてきた⼤学⽣の実験参加者に⽐べて、⼈⼝統計、政治的⽴場、社会における位置付けなどの点から多様性が⾼いため、⼀般有権者の⾦融緩和政策選好についての実験を⾏う上で、より有⽤性が⾼いサンプルであると考えられる。ただし、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者は⽇本の有権者⼈⼝からランダムに抽出されたサンプルではない。したがって、実験のトリートメント効果を超えた調査回答の絶対値について解釈を⼀般化する際には留意が必要である。

②ロジット：IV＝実験群＊イデオロギー、DV=表現の自由規制選好（二値変数、1-3を1、その他を0）、CV＝性別、年齢、収入、教育程度、仕事の有無、政治知識量（事実認識設問の合計）、内閣支持、経済学者信頼度、日本社会の平等認識、日本社会の同質性

という選択肢を選んでもらい、その後に、発言をランダマイズする以下の群が続く。
---
あなたは、公共の場所における表現を政府・⾃治体が規制することに関して、（賛否）とお答えになりました。 この問題に対しては、様々な意⾒がありますが、（①政治・憲法学者の間では、言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基本であり、大変大切なことであると考えら／②現在の上皇陛下は、天皇として在位されていた時に「言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基礎であり大変大切なこと」（平成元年8月4日のお言葉）とお言葉を述べら／③現在の上皇陛下は、平成天皇だった時に「言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基本であり、大変大切なこと」とお言葉を述べられ、また「我が国が朝鮮半島の人々に多大の苦難を与えた一時期がありました。私は先年、このことにつき私の深い悲しみの気持ちを表明いたしました」（平成6年3月24日のお言葉）と）話されています。
---
この後に、もう一度質問を繰り返し、人々の態度変化を分析する。
registration_responses.q12.question: 調査対象者は、オンライン上のクラウドソーシングサービスであるランサーズの登録者プールから、１８歳以上を条件として募集した。三浦・⼩林 (2016) によれば、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者はネット調査のモニタに⽐べて、実験⽂や設問を読まないなど Satisficing と呼ばれる回答努⼒の最⼩限化 (Krosnick, 1991) を⾏いにくい。また、これまでの社会科学における実験で頻繁に利⽤されてきた⼤学⽣の実験参加者に⽐べて、⼈⼝統計、政治的⽴場、社会における位置付けなどの点から多様性が⾼いため、⼀般有権者の⾦融緩和政策選好についての実験を⾏う上で、より有⽤性が⾼いサンプルであると考えられる。ただし、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者は⽇本の有権者⼈⼝からランダムに抽出されたサンプルではない。したがって、実験のトリートメント効果を超えた調査回答の絶対値について解釈を⼀般化する際には留意が必要である。

registration_responses.q19.question:
二標本間のｔ検定、重回帰分析（最小二乗法、ロジット）を使用して分析を行う。以下は、各分析モデルの独立変数（IV）、従属変数（DV)、統制変数（CV）である。

①ｔ検定： IV=実験群＊イデオロギー、DV=表現の自由規制選好（連続変数）
②最小二乗法：IV＝実験群＊イデオロギー、DV=表現の自由規制選好（連続変数）、CV＝性別、年齢、収入、教育程度、仕事の有無、政治知識量（事実認識設問の合計）、内閣支持、経済学者信頼度、日本社会の平等認識、日本社会の同質性
②ロジット：IV＝実験群＊イデオロギー、DV=表現の自由規制選好（二値変数、1-3を1、その他を0）、CV＝性別、年齢、収入、教育程度、仕事の有無、政治知識量（事実認識設問の合計）、内閣支持、経済学者信頼度、日本社会の平等認識、日本社会の同質性

イデオロギーは、次の3種類を使用する。
①自己申告イデオロギー　ideology
②政党支持イデオロギー　party_supp 自民公明日本維新を右派、立憲民主国民民主共産社民れいわ新選組を左派、その他無党派をどちらでもない
③争点イデオロギー　issue の変数を一因子で因子分析、因子スコアを使用。
